settings.text:
When choosing your mechanical switches, you only want the best. The problem is that there are many kinds of switches, and there‚Äôs no easy way to learn and compare them. Luckily, we‚Äôve done the research and created this guide for you!

After you‚Äôve spent time reading this,¬†you‚Äôll have a deeper understanding of mechanical switches, and more importantly, you‚Äôll be able to choose the ones that are best for you.

So let‚Äôs begin!¬† üïπÔ∏è üì± ‚å®

settings.title: Linear Switches
settings.text: Linear switches are smooth and consistent when pressed down. They usually make less noise in comparison to their tactile and clicky counterparts. The switch is fast, which makes it fantastic.

settings.title: Tactile Switches
settings.text: Tactile switches consist of a bump in the middle, which often occurs in the middle of the press. This switch is a middle ground for typing and gaming. It gives enough feedback to ‚Äúfeel‚Äù when a key is pressed, but not requiring to go through a ‚Äúclick‚Äù such as a clicky switch.¬†

settings.title: Clicky Switches
settings.text: The clicky switch has a bump in the middle, but it is followed by a clicking noise. This clicking noise depends on a switch-by-switch basis. Due to the click, it is great for typing ‚Äì giving clear feedback when the key is pressed. It can, however, be a bit harder to game on as it requires for you to go through this feedback, so quick presses might feel less responsive.
